importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Su Yiming won a gold medal in the men's big air snowboarding event at the Beijing Winter Olympics, just days before his 18th birthday, marking a pivotal moment in his career and in Chinese winter sports history.
Su Yiming turned his full attention to professional snowboarding in 2018, after initially gaining fame as a child actor, which marked the beginning of his rise in the snowboarding world.
Su Yiming is preparing for the next Winter Olympics in Italy, where he aims to defend his Olympic title, continuing his legacy as a top-tier snowboarding athlete.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Between 2018 and 2022, Su Yiming transitioned from child actor to professional snowboarder and achieved Olympic success, defining a period of personal and professional transformation in Chinese winter sports.

After his Olympic win, Su took a mental and physical break from competition from 2023 to 2024, using that time to recharge, pursue personal interests, and rebuild his motivation, setting the stage for his return in the upcoming Winter Olympics.

keyTakeAways: Su Yiming's journey from child actor to Olympic champion reflects the power of passion, perseverance, and personal reinvention in achieving success across different fields.
His dual fame in acting and snowboarding demonstrates the growing intersection between entertainment and elite sport in modern China.
Su's experience of post-success burnout and subsequent mental reset highlights the psychological challenges faced by young sporting prodigies.
The global attention Su has received, including from luxury brands and international media, underscores his status as a cultural icon for youth in China and beyond.
His commitment to balance—through family time, nature activities, and diverse hobbies—provides a model for managing fame and pressure in high-profile careers.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Su Yiming, a Chinese snowboarder and former child actor, rose to international fame after winning a gold medal in men's big air snowboarding at the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics. Originally known for his role in the film 'The Taking of Tiger Mountain,' Su transitioned fully to snowboarding in 2018, eventually winning a silver and then a gold at his home Games. After the victory, he faced a period of post-achievement burnout, taking a year and a half off to recharge mentally and physically. During this time, he engaged in nature-based activities like fishing, surfing, and pool, and prioritized family time. Now preparing for the 2026 Winter Olympics in Italy, Su returns with renewed motivation, using the pressure of expectation as fuel. His journey exemplifies how elite athletes balance fame, personal growth, and mental health, while also reflecting broader cultural shifts in China where youth embrace both entertainment and athletic excellence.
